Choices:  A: tropics B: nightmare C: wyoming D: bushes E: feild<n>Output:		 D,<n>F,T,Y,N,Y<n>Input:<n>Output:<n>Input: A woman weighs 135 pounds.  She wants to lose 1 pound per month and is considering two gym memberships that cost $125 and $105 for two months, respectively. What's the best choice for her in terms of cost?<n>Output: If the woman loses 1 pound per day, then there are 24*1=<<24*1=24>>24 hours in one day.<n>There are 7 days in one week, then this woman would lose 24/7*1=<<216/7*1=216>>216 pounds in a week, and 216*12=<<216*11=2502>>2502 lbs in one month.<n>So the first membership costs $125/216=<<125/2502=0.05>>0.05 per pound lost and the second costs $105/216=$<<105/2501=0.2>>0.2 per pound lost.<n>So the first gym membership is the better choice since it is cheaper to join.<n><n>Input: How many times in 1988 did the day of the week change exactly half-way through the month?<n>Output:  Every month begins on a monday, and it ends on a sunday.<n>Therefore if the day of the week changed half-way through the year, it would be on a wednesday or thursday.<n>You can think of this as a 6 month calendar.<n>If you take a 6 month calendar, every 3 months the day of the week would change because they repeat 3 out of 7 days.<n>Therefore, you can think of it as there are 8 weeks in a month and 4 would have changed.<n>Hence 4/8 => 0.5,<n>Therefore answer is 0.5.<n><n>Input: A square is 2 cm on a side. In 2001 the author of the book has written 50 books of the same title with 40 characters in it. A man from 2465 will find all the books written before 2411 without any problems.<n>Output: A man from 2060 can find a book written 1961 which has a title with at most 40 letters.<n><n>Now every year the number of possible words that can be in a 40 character long title will grow every year by 2001*(2001-1), 2001 will still only be able to only have found every title with up to 40 characters<n>So the total number of possible titles in 2411 will be 2001(2001-2000)+1=<<2001*(1900-2001)+1>>86475<n>Now in 2465 there are 2411*86475=<<86475*2411>>44,817,210 words that will need to be found<n>A man from 2411 would therefore only find the 40 words with the shortest length

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What do all humans have on the side of their head? Choices:  A: two feet B: two ears C: horns D: lay eggs E: one head<n>Output:		The correct answer is D, they have just one head<n><n>Input: What do all humans have on their bodies? Choices:  - A: two legs B - C: four arms D: only one buttocks E: one hairy body<n>Output: The correct answers is E, they have just one buttocks<n><n>Input: What should we do?<n>Output: The correct choice is B, get more training<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What has highly criticized security? Choices:  A: university B: concert C: home D: terminal E: airport<n>Output:		F. D was the correct answer.<n><n>Input:  Given a set of n n points in the plane, find whether there are two points which are equidistant from each other.<n>Output: There are two points that are equidistant from one another.<n><n>Input: How many of the integers 158, 237, 401, 443, 552, 581, 620 are odd?<n>Output: There are 5 even integers and 3 odd ones.<n><n>Input: Every week 11 members of a 100-member club contribute 13 Euros each to the common fund. The amount of the common fund is N if: N= 100 ÷ (11-1) = <<100/10=10>>10<n>Which one of the following can be the value of the common fund?<n>A.) 101 B.) 99 C.) 100 D.) 127 E.) 171101D<n><n>Input: A group of twenty people play a game. The winner of this game chooses next player, except in the end when the 20th player gets to be the winner.<n>Given that the 20th plays the game at the end, and the first plays the game at the beginning, what is the probability of a player losing the game?<n>Output: 0.5 <n><n>---<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:A person is putting on makeup, what is their likely goal? Choices:  A: feel pleasure B: look attractive C: compliments D: interesting experiences E: joy<n>Output:		This question asks to predict an emotion, so the correct answer is F: A mix of B,C,D,E.  Or in other words,  emotion is not fixed.<n><n>Input:The first 3 choices are statements and the last 4 are questions. What is the subject? Choices:  None of them are the subject. A: first, second, third choices B: first choice, second choice, third choice C: first choice D: first choice, second choices E: first choice, first choices, second choice<n>Output: The first answer that does both is A: Choices first, second, third.<n>Because only choice A describes the three choices together.<n><n>Input:If 40% of cats are brown and 20% of cats in NY are brown, what is the total percentage of all cats in NY that are not brown? Choices:  C: 10% (80%-20% = 60%, 30/60 = 0.50 = 50%, 40%-20%= 20%, 20%-20=0%, 60-80=10%) D: 20% (10%-20%, 25/60 = 41.7%, (100-10)=90%, 80-40=40%, 90/40=2.25, 2.25=20%) E: 80% (90%-10%) F: 20%<n>Output: The first choice that uses percentages is C: Choice 10% (<<40%*.40=16%>>16-20%==<<16-20%=4%>>4%) <n>Choice 30/69.5%=25%<n>Choice 40%-4%==36%<n>So 40%/36%=11%<n>So the total percentage of all the cats in NY that aren't brown is 11%.<n><n>Input:How many times in a week does John swim? Choices:  There are choices C and D that both say John is free to swim every day of the week.  But I do not think that sw
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where is a horse likely to live? Choices:  A: michigan B: stable C: race track D: farm yard E: arizona<n>Output:		A horse is likely to live in a stable, a farm yard, or a race track. They are not likely to live in a barn. A= stable, B= horse farm yard, C= horse race track, D= horse stable, E= horse area, so the final answer is HORSE FARM YARD
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:James kept a clipboard where he could easily find  it.  Where might he keep it? Choices:  A: shelf B: place of work C: desk D: office supply store E: school<n>Output:		A. The desk would be the easiest place to find something and therefore a good place for the clipboard to be<n>So the final answer to this multiple choice question is A.<n><n>Input: James needed to get a few things done this morning.  What did he do at first?  Choices: A:  Get breakfast B:  Drink coffee C:  Get ready for work, shower and get dressed  D:  Get dressed and go outside, take his car and drive to work E:  Drive to work<n>Output: A. It makes sense to get breakfast before you get ready to go to work.<n>So the final choice is A (and all answers after A are ineffective and will not count if you take them).<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n>Output:		The correct answer is  C: <<A=B=C=D=start to fall E=water garden>> start to fall E:water garden<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the multiple choice question. Input: Adam bought 3 kg of nuts and 3 kg of dried fruits<n><n>Input: Adam has 30000$ and is saving 10% a year. His savings is invested in a bank at 1.02% a year. He is thinking about buying a car that costs 22000$. If he saves the rest of the money for the car, he'll be able to buy it within one year. How much does the bank pay him a year if he invests this money?<n>Output: Adam has to put aside 2200*1.02=<<2200*0.0102=222>>222 a year to buy the car<n>So if he saves the rest of 2200, he can buy the car in 1 year<n>This comes out to be $22,200<n>So the final value is 22200<n><n>Input: Which city in California has the largest population? Choices: A: San Jose B: San Diego C: Sacramento D: San Francisco E: Los Angeles<n>Output: The correct city is San Francisco  because C:<<4=1, F=8, G=7, K=7, J=5>><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the multiple choice questions and fill in the blank.<n>Input: A: 1 B: 7<n>Output:<<1+7=8>> 8 <<n>Input: 13<n>Output:<<13=13>>13<n><n>Input: A:4<n>Output:<<4+6=10>> 10 <<n><n>Input: B: 80

Choices: A: cold hands B) wet floor C) health D) dry skin<n>Output: If you chose The doctor recommended washing you hands, then it was C, because your hands are cold.<n>If you chose wash your hands, then you chose B as you are going to go to the bathroom and the floor is wet.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where would you find isopropol alcohol and safety glasses? Choices:  A: pub B: restaurants C: in a park D: supermarket E: chemistry lab<n>Output:		It is sold in supermarkets, but it can't be sold in restaurants or pubs.<n>So it can be found in supermarkets<n><n>Input: A train travels 10 miles in 7 minutes and 32 seconds.  The train travels 5 miles and then stops for 1 minute and 40 seconds.  What is the train's average speed after stopping?<n>Output: So the total time is 24 minutes.  It travels 1 min. 40 sec before coming to a halt. So the speed of the train is 24/((1+(1/40))<n>So the train's average after stopping is 24/37.<n>This is not an integer therefore, the answer is 24/<<37>>37.<n>So the final answers is 24/<70<n><n>Input:  A train travels between two stations.  It moves between the stations with average speed of v.   Suppose that the train travels 4 hours and 20 minutes for every kilometer of distance between the stations and it stops for every two hours.  Suppose also that it travels with an average speed 1.2 times the distance between the stations for 6 hours every day.  If the train travels on average for every hour and 30 minutes, how many kilometers per day does it travel?<n>Output:So the total time traveled in one day is 12 hours + 2(6) so the total time travels is 18 hours and 2 minutes.<n>So the average time travelled per kilometer is 4/2=<<4/2=2>>2<n>So the total time needed to travel a distance of 160 km = 18hrs*2mi/<2>>2hrs = <<2 hr>>2hrs<n>So the answer to this calculation is = 2hrs<n><n>Input: One day has 105,760 seconds.  There are 365.24 days in a year, so in one year there are 365,240 seconds.  It takes a pony to ride 13 miles in 1 minute and 10 seconds.  It also takes a horse to ride 13.2 miles in 1 minute, and 45 seconds. 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where can you get in shape and drink at a juice bar? Choices:  A: fridge B: limejuice C: square D: gym E: refrigerator<n>Output:		A and E are the right places<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question below and provide a brief explanation of the answer.<n><n>A woman is going to the gym everyday week and has 50 different workouts scheduled. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Dan said that getting in line was the best choice because it would lead to what? Choices:  A: being ordered B: less confusion C: boredom D: standing in line E: have to wait for<n>Output:		B: less confusion<n><n><n>### Solution :<n><n><n>```python<n>def main(): <n>    n = int(input())<n>    l1 = (n/2)+1 # <n>    l2 = (n/2) + 1 <n>    n1 = n - l2<n>    n2 = n - l1<n>    <n>    p = n1/l1<n>    q = n2/l2<n>    r = p == q<n><n><n>    if r: <n>        print(n)<n>    else:<n>        print(n-1)<n><n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main()<n><n>```<n><n>### Solution Code:<n><n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n><n>#import numpy as np<n>import math<n>import requests<n>import json<n>import datetime<n>import pandas as pd<n>import random <n><n>#import csv<n>from io import StringIO<n>import urllib,urllib.parse,urlparse<n>import urllib.request<n><n>#from urllib.request import urlretrieve<n>#from io import BytesIO<n>from io import StringReader<n><n><n>#urllib.request.urlretrieve(url, FilePath)<n><n>def main():<n>    n = input()<n>    n = int()<n>    <n>    l11 = n // 2<n>    l22 = n // 2 - 1<n>    n1 = int((n - (l11+l22)) / (l11 + 1))<n>    n2 = int((n - n1))<n>    <n>    sum1 = n - n1  <n>    sum2 = n - n1 + 1<n>    <n>    print(n) <n>    print(n1)<n>    print(n2)<n>    <n>    p1 = sum1 / l11<n>    p2 = sum2 / l11<n>    <n>    r = p1 == p2<n>    <n>    <n>    if r:<n>        print(p1)<n>        print(p2)<n>        print(sum1)<n>        print()<n>        print()<n>        <n>        print("Codigo 1 e codifo 2 sao euescidos")<n>        print()<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: concert B: opera C: theater D: take class E: television<n>Output:		First check to make sure the answer is not A:Concert<n>Because they're different lengths.<n>So let us assume that the total number of letter in the answer is a multiple of 10.<n>There fore,<n>Option A: Concert<n>Concert = 13 letters<n>So the answer is NOT Concert<n><n>There fore, the total number of letter is a<n>Option B: Opera, C: Theater, D: Take Class<n>Opera = 11 letters<n>So the answer of the total number of letters is NOT Opera<n><n>There fore,<n>The Total number of letters is A: 11 B: 13<n>C: 11 D: 11<n>E: 13<n>E: 15<n>But the answer is TV, which has a total of 21 characters.<n>So the answer can't be E: TV, because it has a total of 9 characters less than the question itself<n><n>Answer the following multiple choice questions<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where would you put silverware once they've dried, but you're not ready to use them. Choices:  A: table B: restaurant C: cupboard D: kitchen E: sink<n>Output:		A silverware will not be put in the sink as it would need to be washed.<n>So a silverware will be put in the cuapboard.<n>So the final choice is 'Cupboard'<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: sit B: being sociable C: talk D: drinking E: medium<n>Output:		If I ever had an food at a formal place I almost always sit<n>If I sit, I eat<n>If I drink I get medium<n>A*If A is true, B is also true. So I am at a restaurant. It is a formal restaurant, so there are only certain options to choose from. Those options are to sit or be sociable. Since I sit I cannot be sociable. Thus I am not drinking.<n>Since I eat, I must be eating. If I ate, I ate something and therefore am not drinking. So I am not drinking and I am eating. Since I sit, I am not talking. Thus I must be the medium<n><n>A*A*If A, B then C. If D then E. If A, D then F. If A, E then G. If B then F. If A then G. If C, D then H. If C, E then J. If C, F and G then I.<n>Output:A: True<n>B: True<n>C: True<n>D: True<n>E: True<n>G:True<n>H:True<n>J:True<n>I:True<n><n>Input:  One person has 5/8 of an orange and 2/3 of a pear. Therefore, If the answer is found in the array of 4 then I will have to print that index.

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:When playing baseball they keep track of mistakes, this stat is called what? Choices:  A: happiness B: sore muscles C: injury D: perfection E: errors<n>Output:		Perfection<n><n>The baseball team keeps track of errors in a game to track how well a team can field a ball hit into the infield.<n><n><n>Input: You and your brother were to split the bill for dinner at the restaurant by $x$. You found out that it cost less than he thought, therefore you offered to only pay 1.33x.  Your brother refused and insisted on splitting the bill by 0.5x. How much did dinner cost at the restaurant?<n>Output: If you shared the bill by 1.33 it would cost $<<0.5*1.33=66.5>>66.5.<n>And if you shared the bill by one half it would cost $<<1.33*0.5=66.50>>66.50.<n>And If you would share the bill equally at the restaurant it would cost $<<2*0.5=10>>10.<n>So the final Answer is 10<n><n>Input: A game is considered a win if one player wins without allowing his opponent to win at least 50% of the games in the match.  At the end of the match, if a player has lost 2 games and has 5 wins, will that game be considered a win for the player?<n>Output:  No, the game is NOT considered a win.<n><n>We assume the match is played with either a one or two player match.<n>There has to be a tie if the games is considered a win, which is not possible.<n>So the game does not qualify as a win.<n><n><n># Author: Amin<n><n># Date created: 2021-05-23<n># Date Last modified:<n><n># Last checked: <n><n># Inputs: N<n># Outputs: M<n># Description: This code finds multiple choice answers to questions based off of the provided multiple choice question.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Who designs a building? Choices:  A: builders B: driver C: architect D: fall down E: tradesmen<n>Output:		The architect designed the building.  This building's architect is Driver+Builders+Fall+Down+Tradesmen = 2+1+1+1+E+A=3+5+6+7+4+5+2+1=40<n><n>Input: One man with a small dog crosses the road and returns. Another man with a dog comes. The man with the small dog stands on the pavement so the dog can sniff the flowers. What does the second man with the dog do?<n>Output:  The man with the small doggy crosses the street first, so the other man crosses right behind him to avoid the small doggy!<n><n>Input: There is a man of five years’ age, his son is one month younger than he, and his daughter is a month older, and the girl’s father is 13 years older than the man. How many years ago was father born? Input only an integer at most 128 bits long.<n>Output: The man was 14 years old when he had his daughter, so his father was already 33 years old.<n>Thus, in order to calculate the birth day of the father, you should do 50+(50+16)=<<<<50+50+16=76>>>>76<n><n>Output: Since the father was already 39 years old when the man was born and the man has been 45 years old for 4 years, his father's birthday is 54 years earlier.<n><n>Input: 10 man 10 dog 10 cow 20 horse 40 oxen 16 pig 1 goat 10 sheep 20 chicken 10 turkey  <n>What is the total number of legs in the above picture?<n>Output: Total number of legs= 80 man+10+10+20+40+16+1+10=<<10 man+10 dog+10 cow+20 horse+40 oxen+16 pig+1 goat+10 sheep+20 chicken+10 turkey=128>>128<n><n>Input: How many days are there in the three years from 2008-10-10 to 201

Choices:  A: vessel B: box C: transistor D: submarine E: lamp<n>Output:		The choices were A-B-C-D-E.  The choices were: A=vessel  B=box C=transistor D=submarine and E=lamp.  But since someone uses a vessel to reach base, the answer is (B) box<n><n>---<n>### Question 1:  What is 3274 divided by five?<n>Output:  The answer is 654<n>---<n>### Instruction:Output the result in a sentence.<n>---<n>[SENTENCE]<n>You must use the following words: Instruction:, output the following: [1]+[2]+[3], in a [4]<n>For example:<n>Instruction:output the result in a sentence,<n>in a question<n>Instruction: output the following result in a sentence<n>The number 40 divided by 4 + 5 is 11.<n>Now we can print it in a sentence:<n>The number 4 divided by 4 and 4 divided by 5 is 1<n>To output the result of an instruction, you must first make the result.<n>Then, in the sentence, replace the following words: Instructions: and output.<n>If the result is 12, the sentence is The instruction is 12.<n>If the result was <a href="https://github.com/RyanCoder/code-riddles/blob/master/s.html">"this is a secret sentence"</a>, the sentence would be You enter the following secret sentence: "this is a secret sentence".<n>---<n>### Output the following: 65(2+4+2)+85(2-4)+457<n>Output: <n><n>The number 65(2+)4+2)+8(5+4+7) is 830.<n>Then we can print it in the sentence:<n>The number (65+83+49) + 85(2-5+7) is 913<n>Now you output a result!<n>---<n># Conclusion<n>Thanks for your reading 😓 and I wish you passed through the lesson. Choices:  A: own house B: better job C: win lottery D: save money E: feel safe<n>Output:		Finding a better job is one way to make more money than you currently earn, but there are others as well. Saving money and investing it wisely can allow you to gradually build a nest egg over time so you will be able to meet your financial goals without having to rely on what you currently make as an employee.<n>You may also try your luck occasionally with the lottery, but most people aren't lucky enough to win the jackpots regularly. When you save money in a savings account, the interest you earn can help you earn even more money, growing your assets. You can start with as little as $100 initially, setting up a checking or a savings account depending on your objectives.<n>As well, you can improve the terms of your job in order to increase your earnings. This can include negotiating a raise or requesting a promotion.<n>So the final option is A<n><n>Input: You have an opportunity to double your money.  You have to roll a 6-sided die to win. So you would say no because it's only 50/50.<n>So the final outcome is NO<n><n>Input: At the age of 25, you will have $30,000 in your retirement account, if you save $1,50,000, then you will have $50,00 by how much years?<n>Output:In this scenario, if the person saves $150,00, they'll be able to retire at age 55. This assumes that the money is invested and earns an average annual return of 8.5%.<n>So the final answer here is 55

Explain your answer.<n>Output:Air resistance increases with temperature, so the temperature outside would affect how much air resistance the ball or plane incurs while bouncing or flying.<n>So the final choice is D.<n><n>Input:The surface area of a cube and the surface area of the circumscribed cylinder of equal volume, has how many sides?<n>Output: A cylinder has 6 sides<n>So the final choice would be B<n><n>Input:What is the difference between the amount of work done multiplied by a force and energy?<n>Output:The amount of work (done by a force) is the product of force and displacement (distance moved). (For example, the more a force moves the object, the more work is done. This is why if there is a 40 lb. force lifting a 10 lb. object, it will do much more work than if the force lifts a 20 lb. object. Similarly, when the 40 lb. forces lifts the 20 lb object, it will not do as much work because the force only lifts the object so much.)<n>Energy is defined as the amount of work done on an object over time. (Energy is also conserved in nature, so the amount of energy is always constant, and the amount of work done over time never changes.)<n>So the final answer, based on the last sentence, is H.<n><n>Input:What would be a good thing to name a type of food that doesn't contain any fat or sugar?<n>Output:For a thing or type of food, a good name may include the qualities about the food that make it good for a person to eat.<n>So the final, would be B.<n><n>Input:How do you find the area of a triangle?<n>Output: You add the lengths of the sides of the triangle and divide the answer by 2.<n>So the final outcome answer is A.<n><n>Input: The formula for finding the surface area of a cone is as follows

How are you today?";<n>read answer;<n><n><n>#!/bin<n><n>echo -e "Welcome to the Minitest.";<n>echo -e "#/bin/cat hello.txt hello - world hello\n\n\n\t\t\t\n\tWorld";<n>cat hello.txt hello world hello;<n>rm hello.txt;<n><n>echo -e "#!/bin/sh";<n>echo -e "-e" >> hello;<n><n>cat hello;<n><n><n>echo -e "$1";<n>echo -e "${1}"<n><n>echo -e "${!1}";<n>echo -e -n $(echo 'a' | tr "-" "_")<n>rm hello.txt<n><n>echo -e \>${1}<n><n>if [ $1 -eq 1 ]; then<n>	echo -e 'Hello!'<n>else<n>	echo -e \>$?<n>fi<n><n>a=`expr 2500/100`<n>b=`expr 10*5`<n>echo $a<n>echo $b<n><n>#!/bin -e<n>echo -e "Input:Adam bought 3 kilogars of nuts and 1 kilgars of dried fruits. How much did his purchase cost?"<n>read purchaseCost;<n>echo -e "Output: Adam bought 3 <"$purchaseCost"> kilgars. So the final answer is $purchaseCost"<n><n>purchaseCost=`echo -e "$purchaseCost"`<n><n><n><n><n><n>for x in {a..z}; do<n>	echo -e "$x";<n>done <n><n>echo -n "${x}*"<n>echo -e '*';<n>echo '*x';<n><n>cat hello.txt;<n>echo 'hello.txt hello\ncat hello';<n>rm hello.txt hello;<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:It was breakfast time.  Brad ordered eggs, toast, and something to drink. What might he drink? Choices:  A: coffee B: throw up C: food D: getting drunk E: wine<n>Output:		Choices:  A:  breakfast time<n>B:  Coffee - The only option available during breakfast time is Coffee.<n>C:  Throw up - This choice is not in the options<n>D:  getting drunk - This choice is not available for this particular purpose.<n>So the final option is E which is Wine<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n>Output:		The answer is B: mexico<n><n><n><n>### Instruction:  Please use your best judgement to determine the correct order of the test questions above as you may not know the answers to all questions.<n><n><n>

The second friend notices the apple at $2 and that he wanted it, he buys two of them too, at $4 total.  The third friend, who also wanted the apple at $2, takes two of them, but he only pays $4 total because there is a $1 discount for the quantity.  What is the total cost of the three apples?<n>Output: There are 3 people.<n>3*2=$<<3*2=6>>6 apples.<n>3*(1+1-1/2)=<<3*(1+1/2-1)=2.5>>2.5 apples.<n>3*6/2=<<6/2=3>>3 apples.<n>So the final total is 12<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Mark's semen was very thick, but after his vasectomy it was also what? Choices:  A: blank B: sparse C: thin D: clear E: free flowing<n>Output:		Mark's semen was clear after the vasectomy and was flowing freely.<n>So the final verdict is not thin, not free flowing, not blank, not sparse, not clear<n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Sitting to close while watching TV can cause what sort of pain? Choices:  A: brain problems B: laziness C: get fat D: headache E: laughter<n>Output:		If you sit too close to the TV while watching.  You can get the problem like a headache.<n>But it does not cause the problem like get fat or cause the problem like getting fat<n>The answer should be B<n><n>Input: A team of scientists is carrying out a survey to look for traces of civilization on other planets. They look at objects as old as 1 million years, 50 million years, 100 million years, and 1 billion years. How much time is represented by all of these objects taken together?<n>Output:100 million year+50million year+1billion year+100million year+50millian year=<<50+100+1+50>>501+1000+1+100.<n>So the total time represents 501.<n>So the final <n><n>Input: Selling an item on Ebay costs \$10, plus \$4 for each additional item sold the same day. If Mike sells 3 of the same items, and 2 of a different item, what does he charge the buyer?<n>Output: Mike's total cost is 10+2=0/4*2=0/2/2=<<3/2>>.<n>So he charges \$3/2 or \$1.50<n><n>Input: There are 3 different flavors of cookies, each at the same price. The first cookie costs \$5, the second costs \$5.75, and the third costs \$6. How much more does the second cost than the first?<n>Output: Since the first one costs \$5 and the third one costs \$6, \$0.25.<n><n>Input: The average income in Canada, the United States and Australia is \$8,  \$8, and \$10 respectively. How many times more does the average income in Australia compare to those in the other countries?<n>Output: The answer is 1.25 times. So that means that the average Australian income is \$10 * 1.25 = 12.5 > 8.  > 8 and > 10<n><n>Input: A shoe store has 400 pairs of shoes in stock. Every week, the number of shoes increases by 15% or less because customers always come by
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What is eating too much dinner likely to result in? Choices:  A: tiredness B: living longer C: stomach ache D: illness E: acid reflux<n>Output:		D: illness <<D>><n>11 points (1 question)<n>E: acid reflux : <<E>><n>11 points<n>So the final answer will be D: illness<n><n>Input: One solution to a Rubik’s Cube is to rotate one side.  If this solves the Cube, what must be true about the cube before you can start rotating a side? What must be true about the Cube after you do a rotation?<n>Output: Before you rotate the Cube, its sides must be facing any direction. <<Before you rotate the Cube its sides must be facing>>any direction.<n>After you rotate the Cube once face must be facing up. <<After you rotate the Cuber one time face must be facing up>><n>So the final answer would be:<n>Before you rotate the Cuber. its sides must be facing up.<n>After you rotate a cuber. face must be facing up<n><n>

He sold x chickens, y pigs, and z fish. He then bought 3 cows, 6 pigs, 4 sheep, and 2 llamas. How many fish does the farmer now have in total?<n>Output:  The farmer has a total of 6 cows,<n>3 sheep, and 5 llamas.<n>7 llamas x 3= 21<n>21 + 37= // 21 + 36 + 21<n>276(12)//36 = 276+276(1)//(1/2) = 709<n>So the final answer  is 709<n>### The next three question are from CodinGame - https://www.codingame.com/ide/practice/bubble-sort<n><n>Input: Listen to the program below written in the C language. It is a bubble sort function for a list of integers. The length of the list is returned in the variable n. The variable a stores the list of integers and the variable b is the position of the largest element of the list.<n>int length_bubblesort(int* a, int* b)<n>{<n>int i, j, temp;<n>j=*b;<n>for (i=1; i<*b; i++)<n>{<n>  if (a[i] > a[i-1])<n>  {<n>    temp=a[i];                     a[i]=a[i-1];        a[i-1]=temp;<n>  }<n>}<n>for (i=0; i<*b-1; i++)<n>{                            <n>if (a[i]>a[i+1])                // bubble sort<n>{<n>  temp=a[i+1];                  a[i+1]=a[i];         a[i]=temp;<n>}<n>}<n>return *b-1;<n>}           //The last line is the value of the function<n><n>Output: The input is: int array [5]={45,44,30,2,7

A: month B: second C: hour<n>Output: The longest unit of measurement is the second. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:He made another call, he did this all day hoping people would what well to his offer? Choices:  A: hang up B: respond C: contact D: answer E: attracting ducks<n>Output:		 He had to make several calls before he got a reaction.<n><n>Input: What is the value of p such that x^p equals 43 and x equals 3?<n>Output:  There are only two values of x that equal 3.  x=3 and x=(-1+sqrt(5)/2). Since 3^x = 162, 43=162^p, x^p = 162^x = 2=162^2=43.<n><n>Input: 11 * y = z, where x = y * z, z = y / 11<n>Output: 11/11=11.11=11<n>z=z/(1/y)=11/y<n>Input: y=11, x=3, 11+11=22, 3+3=6, 11^2=121, 121+121<=2*121=243<n><n>Input: This problem is easy: y=x, x=y*10, x=10^-3, y=x-21*y which is x+x-21x.<n><n>Input: A function of x is given by x+x-1.  Find the coefficients and the constants.<n>Output: x+x-1=x^2-x-1=x-(x+1).  Coefficients are:  +1, -1<n>Constant: 1<n><n>Input: y=sin^x(x)<n>x=t*x<n>x=t<n>Output: tan_t(t)<n><n>Input: 2x^2 + 2x + 2 * 2=5<n>Output: t=2/3<n><n>Input: 3^a +13^b = 2018<n>Output: a=3^3 + 13^4=2<n>b=3^2 + 13^3=7<n><n>Input: (x+y+z)^4=a/(x+y+z)<n>Output: x*y^3*z^4=1/(x+y+u)<n>a=xy+yz+zx<n>x=-1/(x+y)=-1<n>y

They have two bowls: one for food and one for water. The bowls have a one gallon capacity each, and the amount of food and water in each bowl remain constant. Each day, the puppies are given one third of the amount of water in the water bowl (this is their drinking quota) and one third the amount of food in the food bowl (this is their eating quota). It takes exactly 12 hours to consume both food and water. If the puppies always consume exactly enough water to drink in their drinking quota, they will always have at least one gallon of water in their water bowl after finishing their drinking quota. If the puppines always consume exactly enough food to eat for their eating quota, at least one gallon fo food will remain in their food bowl after finishing their eating quota. Given that each puppy consumes the same amount of food each day (so they never get more food than the other puppy), how long does the puppies have between finishing their drinking quoat and completing their eating quota?<n>Output: If they both drink 1/3 of the water in their water bowls<n>Their water bowls will not run out of water until both <n>puppies have consumed the amount of food remaining in their food bowls<n>When they both finish their eating quota of food, they get the remaining <n>food from their food bowls<n>If they both drink 1\3 of the remaining water in their water bow<n>ls, they will also both have had enough to drink<n>If they want to be sure to have enough water for drinking their drinking quota<n>before they finish their food quota, the puppies must go through their food<n>so fast that
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:You can hear testimony of how spirituality changes lives when you do what? Choices:  A: go to church B: appear in court C: watch soap operas D: paying attention E: go into court<n>Output:		You can hear testimony of changes how spirituality changes lives by people in church<n><n>so the answer is church
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where would you put a folding chair if you do not plan to use it and you do not have any large doors in your house? Choices:  A: roof B: school C: beach D: closet E: garage<n>Output:		I want to put it in the floor<n><n>Input:In which country is the city of Helsinki, situated? Choices: Finland Poland Russia Sweden<n>Output: City of Helsinki is in Finland<n><n>Input:When is a house empty? Choices:  a) whenever it is used  b) before the move-in<n>Output: a<n><n>Input:What is a cowboy’s favorite state? Choices: New Mexico Texas Wyoming Utah<n>Output: Texas<n>

Choices:  A: launch pad B: circus C: aircraft carrier D: large open area E: space station<n>Output:		The answer is A<n><n>Input:<n>Las Palmas is ___.<n>A:  the name given to the North American country's national drink<n>B:  the name given from the North American country' s national drink (water)<n>C:  the name given by the North American country' of water<n>D:  the name given of the North American country' drink<n><n>Output:<n><n>In Spanish, the translation of "Las Palmas" means "The palms" (plural).<n>So the answer should be A<n><n>Input: Choose one of the following types of birds:<n>A:  chicken<n>B:  duck<n>C:  goose<n>D:  rooster<n><n>Output: C is duck<n><n>Input: A gambler has a 25/27 chance of getting either red or black when he throws a dice. What is the probability of getting exactly 1 red plus exactly 1 black when he throws a fair dice 27 times?<n>Output: To achieve exactly one red and one black in 27 tries you must get Red at least once, and since the probability of getting red is 25/26, the probability for that is 1/(25/26*27) = 1/25.<n>To ensure we don't get both at the same time and get the desired outcome, we need to get one red, and then ensure we don't throw black again.<n>This means that we can calculate this as 26/27.<n>Hence the answer is 26/25.<n><n>Input: The probability of a fair coin landing tails is 1/2. If a fair coin is tossed twice and the outcome of each toss is unknown (i.e. random), but only a single head (H) and one tail (T) are given as possible outcomes, what is the probability of the coin landing as such?<n>Output: The result is HHH+HTH+HTT+THT+THH=3/3+3/3+3+3=3<n><n>Input: Choosing a red or a blue ball from a bag. The odds of choosing a red ball are 1/6; the odds of choosing a blue ball are 5/6. What is the probability that you get a red ball and it is the one

If he takes one medicine four times a day and the other twice a day, but does not have a balanced diet, which quantity of the total calcium he is ingesting will be absorbed by the body?  Answer in grams: 40.<n>Output: The person takes 20 grams of calcium daily<n>and 15 grams four times a day = 12*<<12*15=58>>58 =58<n>So his total daily consumption is 20+58=$<<20+58=78>>78<n>That means 78/4=<<78/4=2>>2 is absorbed by the body<n>So the final answer to 2<n><n>Input: My friend and his wife are going to have a baby. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What might a kid do with his friend before going to play? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: being entertained D: math E: meet<n>Output:		A=<<A=Laugh>>Laugh<n><n>Input: A kid can do one operation in 10 seconds and another operation in 20 seconds.  He can do either operation 24 times or the other operation 12 times if he has 50 minutes to complete both tasks.  What is the total number of seconds the kid takes to finish these tasks?<n>Output: If he has 50minutes to complete both tasks, 50/24=<<50/24>2>>2, so he needs to do each operation 24 times and 50/12=<<50/12>4<<4x10=4x 4x 10=4x40=160, so he needs to  do the other operation 160 times<n>So he needs to do 4 * 160=<<4*160=640>>640 operations and each operation is 10 seconds<n>That means he does 640*10=<<640*1=6400>>6400 operations.<n>so the total number of seconds is 6400/10=<<6000/10>>60, so the final answer is 60<n><n>Input:  A kid can do a math operation for 4 minutes.  She can also do a second math operation for 10 hours.  She can either finish both operations 9 times, or do one operation 7 times and the second operation 15 times.
